Title: Memory access on the Apple M1 processor
Description: When a program is mostly just accessing memory randomly, a standard cost model is to count the number of distinct random accesses. The general idea is that memory access is much slower than most other computational tasks. Furthermore, the cost model can be extended to count “nearby” memory accesses as free.
